author: __lithp__
content:
Hi everyone, I'm not sure where to ask this, hope this is the right place.

What's the plan deal with rational miners during the switchover from ETH1 -> ETH2. The coinbase isn't spendable for x blocks, so if miners believe that the transition is going to happen, then they believe that they have no way of spending any reward they get from mining the x blocks before the switchover to ETH2 happens, so won't they just stop mining?

author: ajsutton
content: Coin base in Ethereum is immediately spendable and I strongly suspect any plan to migrate would include moving the entire eth1 balances at the end of that chain into eth2. Details are still being researched for how that transition would work though.

author: ajsutton
content: Or I should say block reward and transaction fees are immediately spendable. They are credited to the account in the coin base header as part of finalising block processing.

author: ralexstokes
content: <@!296630428754771968> there are some more details in a proposal here: https://ethresear.ch/t/the-eth1-eth2-transition/6265

author: ralexstokes
content: i think it depends on how extreme we want to change the eth1 protocol during a merge -- we could effectively pause the chain and do a bunch of "upgrades" when moving the state root under the eth2 consensus

author: ralexstokes
content: i dont think the concern is miners stopping mining early (they should be able to generate block rewards through the last proof-of-work block) but more that miners could keep mining a fork of the proof-of-work chain in the event that they don't want to support the transition to eth2

author: ralexstokes
content: i think it is generally accepted though that the norms in the community called "Ethereum" have planned on this transition since the beginning so i would put the probability of such  fork (and esp one that sees a lot of use) pretty low

author: __lithp__
content: Thanks <@!340345049063882753> , you're right, I had thought Ethereum copied Bitcoin but you made me look at geth and the coinbase is indeed immediately spendable

author: __lithp__
content:
> i dont think the concern is miners stopping mining early (they should be able to generate block rewards through the last proof-of-work block) but more that miners could keep mining a fork of the proof-of-work chain in the event that they don't want to support the transition to eth2
> 

Oh, they'll definitely do this! Won't they? If there's any chance that the transition won't go through they'll want to have been collecting rewards from the PoW chain, and there's no good way to punish them for trying

author: ralexstokes
content: sure but hopefully we can keep our "chain pause" to a short period of time so that it becomes obvious that the transition was successful

author: ralexstokes
content: so that miners can spin down hardware w/in some small number of blocks after the Last Block (TM)

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**SamWilsn**
I mean, even if the transition succeeds, aren't miners incentivized to continue mining anyway? Ethereum Super Classic (TM)

author: ralexstokes
content: it is possible that you may be able to contribute to the eth2 network as a state provider or even join as a validator and join the eth1x shard so that you aren't just suddenly jettisoned from the ecosystem/community after the Last Block (TM)

author: ralexstokes
content: it is possible we will be stuck w/ ethcash (what i have been calling ethereum super classic) indefinitely

author: ralexstokes
content: as eth2 enthusiasts it is somewhat on us to encourage a thorough migration to the new system once it is ready

author: ralexstokes
content: w/ incentives if possible but moreover also via social coordination off chain, (e.g. historical norms to move to proof-of-stake, showing network stability w/ the new system, this kind of stuff)

author: ajsutton
content: It does make me wonder if a 2-way eth bridge and running ETH2 and ETH1 in parallel makes sense for a good while so people see just how much better ETH2 is and want to migrate. But part of being better is being able to utilise the existing ETH1 stuff so ETH1 winds up having to at least act like an ETH2 shard even if it's still PoW driven.  And then it all gets weird and I see why people want to bundle ETH1 into a shard asap. ðŸ™‚
